title: meeting to discuss crossing points
story: Jim McGregor, an engineer for BEAR Scotland, the company which maintains Scotland#s trunk road network on behalf of Transport Scotland, will be in attendance, alongside representatives from Police Scotland, Campbeltown Community Council, Kintyre Crime Prevention Panel, and Argyll and Bute councillors, including Donald Kelly who arranged the meeting after campaigning for safer crossings for a number of years.The main issues to be discussed are the removal of the red markings at the current pedestrian crossing points in the town the removal of the crossing point at the Royal Hotel the provision of a crossing at the Aqualibrium and the provision of a crossing at the Co-op.This comes after a questionnaire-type survey was carried out earlier this year despite a Transport Scotland officer indicating to Councillor Kelly that Campbeltown#s A crossing points were not a priority.Concerns have also been raised for some time by Campbeltown Community Council about what it considers unsafe crossings at the Co-operative and the Royal Hotel, where it is felt visibility is poor.The issue has become even more pertinent with childcare now offered in the Aqualibrium since Argyll and Bute Council extended its provision of free early learning and childcare to , hours per year in Campbeltown.Anne S Paterson, the council#s chief education officer, said: #This will entail increased pedestrian footprint to the Aqualibrium and parents, carers and young children will be crossing the main road to gain access to the building. For this reason we would support a crossing being in place.#Councillor Kelly added: #This has been a long-running saga. Hopefully this meeting will have a successful outcome with the removal of the road markings at the Royal Hotel and new permanent crossings installed at the Co-op and Aquilibrium.#I fully appreciate this will not be ideal, however we will need to compromise to achieve any kind of a result.#The meeting will be held at pm on Tuesday July  at the Royal Hotel.Councillor Donald Kelly has arranged the meeting after years of campaigning for safer crossings. _cdonaldkellyAlan Baker, chairman of Campbeltown Community Council which has also campaigned for safer crossings, plans to attend the meeting. He is pictured here at the Royal Hotel crossing. _cbaker

title: plan-to-turn-prestonpans-town-hall-into-a-digital-paradise
story: Prestonpans Community Council is bidding to take control of the High Street venue and turn it into an audio-visual and digital haven.A sub-committee of the community council that was formed when the option for a Community Asset Transferof the Town Hall to the group was first offered has come up with a lsquodigital destinationrsquo concept ndash and garnered positive feedback from the community council.The community council is the only group to have put in a note of interest for the Town Hall, and the sub-committee ndash featuring DJ Johnston Smith, Calum Miller and Professor Roger Bromley ndash has now made public its vision for the building.Their initial idea is to create an audio-visual centre within the Town Hall for gamers and competitions, as well as running educational classes on technology and creating a ldquodigital destination for all with k audio-visual displays, fibreoptic network, high-speed computers, floor space and a cafe.In the subcommittee strategy, the members state: ldquoThe activities which once occupied our Town Hall are not filling it today we need to think creatively to identy new audiences.ldquoAll of the traditional activities can now be accommodated where in our town.ldquoOur Town Hall needs to offer something unique to the community: our challenge is to use our assets to create richer social interactions for all.ldquoWe live in a world where the social networks that helped us advance are increasingly replaced by the digital iety. We are all engaging more online, but the conversations are getting shorter and colder.ldquoThese conversations would be more positive and productivewe could host them in a social context.ldquoWhatrsquos needed is a lsquoFaceFaceBookrsquo where the digital world is used to increase the physical interaction.They have suggested that a large screen cover the back of the building behind the stage that could act as a cinema screen, a digital backdrop to a theatre show and a space for presentations and gaming competitions.Although it is only in the very early stages of planning, the concept was well received by the community council, with member Ferhan Ashiq saying that he was ldquovery impressed with the bold and innovative idea.The community council has the option to either lease or buy the Town Hall from East Lothian Council, and this decision has not been officially made yet but will be the next step that is taken, discussing a business plan and the terms of the transfer with the local authority.The approach is laid out in the strategy, which states that the community council will ldquoreview the best practice from where and arrange research visits to similar facilities. We then refine our idea, seeking feedback from people in Prestonpans. Then we follow the commercial path of least resistance, working with East Lothian Council and other bodies. We bootstrap the idea ASAP with initial funding needed to install the equipment, secure and manage the premise. Then we use the success of the venue to fundraise for improvements and enhancements to the structure of the building to renovate the interior.Brian Weddell, chair of the community council, said: ldquoI was delighted that the feedback from community council members was  per cent positive.ldquoIt is an exciting and imaginative use of a grossly under-used community asset that could help kickstart the revitalisation of Prestonpans High Street.The Town Hall was identied as one of the six viable properties across the county suitable for a CAT, offering local organisations the chance to lease or buy them.

title: preview-3-harbours-festival
story: Residents and visitors alike can enjoy art galleries, live music events, family afternoons with pebble decorating and ukulele orchestras, open houses, cooking demonstrations and workshops over the course of the festival, which runs from Saturday to next Sunday .The festival, which was started more than  years ago, is going from strength to strength, expanding and becoming more erse, with something for everyone in its programme.For the live music fans out there, there is a chance to see the Tom Fairnie Band play their famous Americana music supported by Paul Brown, then Andy Brown, Dropkick and Fuzzystar for the Indie lovers, Alex Hodgson and Rhys Heaven for the folk fans, and to get an eclectic mix all in one sitting, there are the Live on the Lawn sessions, an afternoon of music in the majestic Cockenzie House and Gardens .To keep the young ones and old ones entertained all at once, this year will see a Harbour Family Afternoon added to the programme. Wool spinning, ukulele orchestra, pebble decorating, sign writing and live music will grace Port Seton Harbour as the festival celebrates the communityrsquos links to the sea.This sea celebration continues with the event Putting to Sea that includes intergenerational conversations, songs and stories from those who have lived, worked and put out to sea from Port Seton Harbour.For the foodies out there, the festival has three Tasty Notes events which involve food demonstrations with interesting food concoctions alongside live music, again at Cockenzie House and Gardens.An Arts and Crafts Fair and a Therapy Taster will all be on offer for those looking for new ways to relax body and soul, as well as makers from all over East Lothian showing their work, with kiddie face paints in the gardens and storyteller Tim Porteus taking a childrenrsquos writing and painting workshop.The streets will be lined with buskers, providing a live music soundtrack for those exploring the streets and making their way to venues with many more events and exhibitions to enjoy.Festival organisers Jane Brown and Rebecca Dover have said that this year there is something for everyone at the festival.For a full programme of events for the festival, visit harbours

title: new-museum-exhibition-celebrates-history-musselburgh-festival
story: Past Honest Lads and Honest Lasses have rallied round with support by donating items of memorabilia for the display, which includes photographs of past events, riding boots, stirrups and a riding crop.The iety of gts presented by local industries and the community to Honest Lads and Honest Lasses at sashing ceremonies can been seen, as well as trophies for events such as the Honest Ladsrsquo Race, Ladiesrsquo Race and Crusaders Riding Club competition.There is a chance to get a close-up look at sashes embroidered with the names of every Honest Lad and Honest Lass from  to  and the Burgh Standard, which plays an important role during the annual festival.Official outfits worn by the Honest Lad and Honest Lass are exhibited, as well as programmes, pennants, the first minute book for festival organisers the Honest Tounrsquos Association and words for the Musselburgh Song. Information is on show about the carriage used on election night, when the official party is transported through local streets to waving crowds.The birth of the festival in , when Jimmy Arthur was Honest Lad and Ina Vass, Honest Lass, is also outlined.This yearrsquos Honest Lad Aidan Maguire, Honest Lass Claire Dougal and attendant Abbie Thomson were amongst the first to enjoy a tour of the exhibition after their recent visits to local primary schools and Musselburgh Grammar School.Stefanie Talac, honorary secretary of the Honest Tounrsquos Association , said this was the first exhibition about the festival at the museum and they hoped that as many people as possible would pay it a visit.She said: ldquoWe are delighted at the way the exhibition has turned out. We had a lot of help from past Honest Lads and Honest Lassies.ldquoThere is a beautully bound photograph album from the Honest Lass of  which was presented by the local paper mill. Our th year Honest Lass was presented with a travel iron from Brunton Wire Mill. The connection with the fishing community in Musselburgh is also shown in the gts with a ship in a bottle and model boats.She added: ldquoDuring the festival, the Honest Lass pins a pennant to the top of the flag and it has the Honest Ladrsquos name on it. Each pennant is in the museum as well.Stefanie said that while the festival is on from July  to  this year, some of the display items will be removed as they will have a part to play in the event itself, before being ed to the museum afterwards.She added: ldquoThe museum is a great asset to the town. We are really pleased that we have had the opportunity to have the exhibition in the museum. It is the first since the museumrsquos inception and hopefully we will do so again in the future. The exhibition is here for people who want to learn more about the festival and we hope they do.The museum at  High Street is open Thursday to Saturday, .am to pm.

title: north-berwick-high-school-roll-set-top-1-000-extension-planned
story: The school, which welcomes pupils from the surrounding villages as well as North Berwick, currently has a school roll of .However, that figure is expected to increase, with the town continuing to grow and the school set to become the fourth secondary school in the county with more than , pupils.Three extensions ndash in ,  and  ndash have already been carried out on the school to accommodate the growth of the town.Now, the proposed extension would cater for a school roll of up to ,.Plans submitted to East Lothian Council note: ldquoThe completed building will provide state-of-the-art teaching and social space facilities in line with the clientrsquos brief as well as promoting energy efficiency and offering facilities which signal the high value placed on learning at North Berwick High School.ldquoThe project is to reflect the standards commensurate with a modern school facility and provide a high-quality environment that will inspire both staff and young people to achieve their full potential.The proposed extension would occupy an area to the south-west of the existing buildings, bordered by the synthetic pitch and the site boundary with the schoolrsquos neighbours Law Primary School.The document states: ldquoThe location of the proposed extension will offer views out over the sports pitches and towards North Berwick Law.The ground floor of the three-storey extension will become home to the home economics department, with a shared social and exhibition space.Social sciences will be based on the first floor, with the languages department on the second floor and ldquolarge shared breakout spaces at the heart of the floorplan.The plans from Innovate East Lothian Ltd, which is acting on behalf of East Lothian Council, could go before the local authorityrsquos planning committee later this year.Currently, Dunbar Grammar School , Musselburgh Grammar Schooland Ross High Schoolin Tranent all have more than , pupils.

title: council-remove-recycling-wheelie-bins-contamination
story: East Lothian Council is one of the few local authorities in Scotland to retain recycling boxes for most of its households and has a  per cent recycling rate ndash higher than the national average.However, Tom Reid, the councilrsquos head of infrastructure, revealed that it had rolled out , communal recycling bins in small communities and densely populated streets.But, he said, the result had been a much higher contamination level in the recycled waste which suggested thatbins were rolled out across the county it could cost the council up to poundmillion. The bins, first used in , are now being removed by the council and replaced with inidual boxes.Mr Reid told a meeting of the councilrsquos policy and performance review committee that the bins had not been a success.Councillor Gordon Mackett asked why wheelie bins could not be used, saying he was told by people they ldquowould recycle morethey had wheelie bins.But Mr Reid said: ldquoUsing the boxes produces a higher quality of recycling waste and we currently sell it for up to pound,.ldquoWe have , wheelie bins out there and the result has been a disappointing  to  per cent contamination.ldquoIf we moved to wheelie bins we would have to pay out between poundmillion to poundmillion to decontaminate the materials.A council spokesperson said the recycling bins had already been removed from some parts of the county, with the rest expected to be replaced by boxes in the near future.

title: stars-music-sport-tv-head-east-lothian-scottish-open-pro-am
story: The Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open gets under way next Thursday , with some of the worldrsquos top golfers looking to gain momentum heading into The Open.Twenty-four hours before competition gets under way, Tartan Wednesday s to the competition, along with the Pro-Am tournament.Fans are encouraged to join players and celebrities by donning tartan in aid of the tournament charities: My Namersquo Doddie Foundation, Leuchie House and the European Tour Foundation.Television presenters Dan Walker and Naga Munchetty, who regularly share the sofa on BBC Breakfast, will be joined by TV personality and regular Hero Challenge host Vernon Kay.Frontman for Scottish rock band Twin Atlantic Sam McTrusty is joined by comedian-turned-radio presenter Fred MacAulay and talkSPORT presenter Georgie Bingham.Staying in sport, Winter Olympian Eve Muirhead will also join what promises to be a fun day out on the golf course.In a battle of the Irish boy bands, Boyzone singer Keith Duffy and singer-songwriter and former Westle vocalist Brian McFadden will also tee it up.Former Scotland and British Lions lock forward Doddie Weir revealed in June  that he had been diagnosed with motor neurone disease. In November that year, he and his trustees launched the My Namersquo Doddie Foundation to raise funds to aid research into the causes of motor neurone disease and investigate potential cures.Leuchie House, near North Berwick, is Scotlandrsquos only dedicated respite centre and offers caring respite breaks to people with long-term neurological conditions, including motor neurone disease.By providing the care they need, Leuchie is able to support people with many dferent conditions to have fulfilling, revitalising breaks, while giving their carers time away from caring.The two charities joined the European Tour Foundation ndash which works with charities, players, governing bodies and partners to ensure a lasting legacy in the countries where the European Tour plays ndash as official charity partners of the Scottish Open in , and will once again benefit from a range of fundraising activities throughout tournament week, including Tartan Wednesday.The Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open is being played for the first time at The Renaissance Club, which was founded in  and nestles on  picturesque acres along the Firth of Forth. Tickets for the Pro-Am are pound for adults and pound for juniors.

title: kind-pupils-help-raise-money-beach-wheelchairs-project
story: Youngsters at The Compass School collected an impressive pound. through an enterprise sale at the Haddington school, with the money going to North Berwick-based Beach Wheelchairs.The schoolrsquos pupil council identied the good cause as one of the three main charities to support throughout the year.Beach wheelchairs enable people with disabilities to access the beach through using specially designed wheelchairs created to travel over the sand and even into the water.The scheme was first set up in  and, since then, similar facilities have been established in Portobello and at Seton Sands.The enterprise sale, which took place before the end of the schoolrsquos term, saw children designing and making a range of dferent items, from artwork to baking and from origami creations to practical items to use at home.The sale followed on from a successful Swimathon earlier this year, with youngsters ing in to raise funds for WaterAid.Mark Becher, headmaster at the school on West Road, was proud of the pupils.He said: ldquoI was delighted when the children of our pupil council chose Beach Wheelchairs as one of the principle charities they would be supporting this year.ldquoThe charity does so much fantastic work and has opened up the beautul beaches of East Lothian for those who previously had very restricted access or none at all. The children greatly enjoyed creating and making for the enterprise sale, which saw a vast range of goods for sale.ldquoTo achieve this total is testament to their efforts and the generosity of all those who supported them.ldquoWe would like to thank everyone who assisted the children in this very successful initiative.Last week, a group of staff and children from the pupil council visited Melanie Kay at Beach Wheelchairsrsquo facility in North Berwick.The children had the opportunity to view all of the wheelchairs and to meet with a family who had travelled from the west of Scotland in order to use a wheelchair.The pupils spoke to the family about the benefits of the charity and they all observed the importance of these chairs first-hand.

title: princess-anne-makes-special-visit-leuchie-house
story: EAST Lothian played host to a distinguished guest as the Princess Royal made a special visit to the county.Her Royal Highness Princess Anne paid a visit to Leuchie House, the respite care centre near North Berwick which offers respite breaks for people with a iety of long-term conditions as well as their carers, last Thursday.The Princess Royal previously visited Leuchie in  and launched the lsquoLeuchie Forever Fundrsquo, a new fundraising initiative for the charity, of which she became patron. She also visited in .On her latest visit, the Princess ndash who was described as a ldquolovely lassie by one guest ndash was greeted by Mark Bevan, chief executive, and Bob Brannan, chair of the fund, and taken to meet Leuchiersquos guests, staff, supporters, patrons and trustees.The meeting was held in Leuchiersquos lounge, with a series of paintings hanging on the walls created by Rachel Mylne, who had turned  two days prior to the royal visit.Money raised by the Leuchie Forever Fund had allowed the lounge to be redecorated, and when hanging the paintings on the wall a signature from the s, a mark from a previous painter, was discovered.On her arrival at Leuchie, Princess Anne first met some of the guests and their carers. She asked questions including ldquoHow did you find out about this place  and ldquoHow long have you been coming here  She listened to their stories and the dference Leuchie had made in their lives.Moving on to the trustees, donors and patrons, she was interested in hearing how they had discovered Leuchie and how they had become involved in the charity.Among those present was Scottish rugby legend Gavin Hastings, who is also a patron of Leuchie.Describing his involvement in the charity, he said: ldquoItrsquos a great place to come along and itrsquos great to support the work that they do here because they do such great work ndash not just here in Leuchie but all over Scotland.After meeting the Princess, many praised her humour and willingness to take the time and talk to everyone, listening to their stories. Others mentioned how hardworking and well-briefed she was and how much she knew about Leuchie.Regular guest Iain Elder described the Princess as ldquoa lovely lassie, while others praised her interest and passion for the charity.Jim Maxwell, who is the primary carer for we Jane, a guest at Leuchie, said of his conversation with the Princess: ldquoShe asked where we lived and how we managed to find Leuchie House. I told her as a carer it is very important for the both of us to come here.ldquoShe really took the time to speak to us and hear our story.Afterwards, some of the guests gave a speech where they explained how much Leuchie House had helped them.Alex MacCarthy-Morrogh has multiple sclerosis and visits Leuchie every Tuesday as a day guest. As well as attending physio and fitness classes, which he describes as essential for his physical and mental wellbeing, he talks to fellow guests to keep them company.He said: ldquoI come here to help myself and to give my we a break and give her some freedom. Me being here, she knows Irsquom safe which is very important to me.ldquoThis place is important to the people here, therersquos no other place like it. They treat you like a person and see you beyond the wheelchair.His we Susie said: ldquoItrsquos great when Alex comes here. Falling is his biggest concern and I donrsquot worry he is going to fall when he is here. Him being safe is so important to me and they really look after him and everyone here.Mairi OrsquoKeefe, patron and former chief executive of Leuchie House, said: ldquoPrincess Anne loves the work we do here and the respiratory things that we do everyone gets physio and everyone gets a respiratory assessment. She also sees what it does for the guests.ldquoShe really cares about Leuchie.A tour of Leuchie followed, with Princess Anne meeting one volunteer who wrote the calligraphy on the invites and who gave the Princess a humorous wink.When speaking to the dieticians, Princess Anne expressed how dficult it must be to keep up with a iety of dferent diets.She took an interest in one, a soon-to-be graduate, asking about her experience in Leuchie in relation to her studies and saying: ldquoYoursquove probably come across more diets here than on your course!Her tour led on to the art room, while in the TV room Princess Anne met one guest who had been coming to Leuchie since , jokingly saying: ldquoYoursquore keeping them on their toes!The Princess was taken into a further lounge and met a man taking part in a virtual reality experience.When she noticed he was in London, she said: ldquoI know London very well. She was told he caught a whale earlier ndash ldquonot in the Thames, I hope, she replied.Mark Bevan, chief executive of Leuchie, said: ldquoWe were thrilled to welcome HRH The Princess Royal, and patron of the Leuchie Forever Fund, to Leuchie House once again and for her to meet and thank our many supporters.ldquoShe saw first-hand the importance of providing quality respite to our guests and their carers.ldquoThe visit was a wonderful experience for our guests and colleagues who were able to spend time with Her Royal Highness. She spoke to them about their experiences and the dference that spending time at Leuchie makes to their lives and those of their carers.Bob Brannan, chairman of the Leuchie Forever Fund, said: ldquoThe Princess has taken time since becoming our patron three years ago to really understand Leuchie.ldquoToday as on previous occasions, she has used this understanding to encourage our many generous supporters to ensure Leuchie can continue to develop and provide such a great service to so many people across Scotland for years to come.As the visit came to an end, the Princess signed the visitorsrsquo book and was presented flowers and a card by Rachel Mylne, who said: ldquoThank you for all your hard work, we are very grateful. Leuchie is a wonderful place, will you try and keep it going Princess Anne replied: ldquoI will definitely try my best.

title: thousands-expected-attend-aberdeen-standard-investments-scottish-open-renaissance-club
story: Thousands of fans are expected to flock to East Lothianrsquos Golf Coast between today and Sunday as the competition heats up.Among those taking part are four-time Major winners Rory McIlroy and Ernie Els, Scotlandrsquos last Major champion Paul Lawrie and former world number one Justin Thomas.Brandon Stone, who won the tournament at nearby Gullane Golf Club  months ago, is joined by Rickie Fowler, who lted the title at the same club in .Action gets under way at .am with Joakim Lagergren, Oliver Wilson and Scott Henry taking to the course.North Berwickrsquos Grant Forrest also has an early start as his bid for the title begins at .am alongside Matthieu Pavon and Andy Sullivan.Former Dunbar Grammar School pupil David Drysdale tees off at .pm alongside Andrew Johnston and Erik Van Rooyen, with McIlroy and Fowler playing alongside Robert MacIntyre from .pm.The final round of the day tees off at .pm with Steven Brown, Ben Evans and Justin Walters taking to the course.The Pro-Am was played at the course yesterday .

title: new-homes-over-60s-longniddry-welcomed
story: East Lothian Council gave the go-ahead for nearly  new houses in three separate applications to its planning committee.One application for four houses and  flats revealed that all its units would be for older people.The housing, which is on land identied for potentially having up to  new homes on it, to the south of Longniddry, will be taken by Castle Rock Edin Housing Association once built.A planning application before the committee revealed: ldquoAll of the residential units would be for independent living for people aged over  years.The flats will mainly be in two-storey buildings, with one three-storey building and four bungalows which will be built around a courtyard-style quadrangle.Two additional applications included one for  houses and  flats, all of which will be for private sale, and another for  houses and  flats, of which only two houses and eight flats will be affordable.Places for People, which is overseeing the over-s housing and  private properties, welcomed the decision as the ldquofirst phase in the Longniddry South development.Willie Lockhart, Places for People interim director of development for Scotland, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have the go-ahead to begin building at Longniddry. It promises to be a truly special development offering benefits to both new and existing residents of the village.The layout of the development, on land owned by the Wemyss and March Estate, sees housing designed by architect Ben Pentreath to reflect traditional East Lothian homes, and the committee was shown a walkthrough video depicting what the streets will look like.Ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said: ldquoI welcome the decision to provide affordable housing for over-s in Longniddry.ldquoIt is an issue for people wanting to downsize from their properties which are then freed up for families who want to move in.Representatives of Longniddry Community Council attended the meeting to raise concerns about some of the infrastructure surrounding the new housing. But they told the committee they had no objections to the development itself.Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning convenor, encouraged the community council to contact the local authority with any concerns about issues during the development of the new housing.And council leader Willie Innes praised the members of the community council for attending.He said: ldquoThe community council raise valid concern which will need to be addressed by the developers. They are not opposing it in principle and we want to work with the community to manage the process.He added: ldquoI think this development is something special and something dferent and will make a positive impact on Longniddry and East Lothian.Rock Feilding-Mellen, from Socially Conscious Capital, which worked with the landowners to develop a masterplan for the entire site, welcomed the plansrsquo approval.He said: ldquoWe are thrilled that Zero C can now start building these much-needed new homes and turning our carefully designed masterplan and design code into a beautul st-century extension to Longniddry.ldquoWe trust that residents and members of the wider community who contributed throughout the many consultations will feel that their time and effort has paid off when they finally get to see the results.

title: knox-academy-half-marathon-team-raise-2-000
story: Eleven S pupils were joined by half a dozen members of staff at the Edinburgh Marathon Festivalrsquos half-marathon start line.The Knox Academy group all donned special t-shirts highlighting they were running for East Lothian Special Needs Playscheme .The school has formed a strong bond with the charity, which provides full-day playschemes during school holidays for children aged five to  with a wide range of special needs disabilities, and previously secured pound, for the good cause through a Youth Philanthropy Initiativescheme.Lana Borwick, PE teacher, was among those taking part.She said: ldquoThere was a real sense of community around the event.ldquoAll the participants took to the lsquoPink Penrsquo to give each other final words of support and encouragement before the early start on the day.ldquoAlmost all of the Knox Academy runners were making their half marathon debut which was a real test of their commitment to training and they didnrsquot disappoint, with everyone completing the challenge despite the poor weather conditions ndash some in remarkable times!ldquoIt was a wonderful occasion and we are all very proud of what wersquove managed to achieve together, ultimately impacting on the opportunities that the playscheme can continue to provide to youngsters in our community.ldquoIt was great also to see so many people brave the weather to come out and cheer us on, both from our school community and from the Playscheme, which really helped as the legs started to tire!ldquoEvents like this serve as a fantastic reminder to us of the commitment, enthusiasm and drive that our young people have to make a dference in society.Joining Miss Borwick, who completed the .-mile course in a time of :., at the finish line were pupils Matthew Black , Dylan Brotherston , Isabelle Bowen , Elliot Cochrane , Harry Cunningham , Hana Elder , Adam Fairgrieve , Mateusz Juchniewicz , Max Leveque , Daniel Mackinnonand Lauren Taylor , as well as Robert Flood, Susanne Fox, Thomas Salkeld, Suzie Stewart and Alex Redford .Kirsty Milne of ELSNP was ldquoblown away by the support.She said: ldquoThe team have signicantly raised our charityrsquos profile by embarking on such a tremendous fundraiser and we are extremely thankful to them for the incredible amount raised.ldquoWe have strengthened links with Knox Academy over the years, with many of their pupils past and present volunteering at or attending our playscheme and youth club provisions and it is amazing to see the school uniting to support our local cause.ldquoWe cannot thank the runners enough for their incredible efforts and for raising such a large sum of money.ldquoOur playschemes will be running for the full six weeks of the summer break and, thanks to the generous donations from the Edinburgh Marathon Festival, we will be able to offer many fun trips and outings to those attending.ldquoThere is something really special about seeing local young people coming together to support their peers and we are thankful to all at Knox Academy for their support.

title: bid-third-pharmacy-tranent-turned
story: The application was presented to the Pharmacy Practice Committee , which decided that the town was already suitably served by its current pharmacies.The committee also stated that there was too long a wait between the Consultation Analyst Reportand the hearing as over a year had passed, which it felt rendered the findings out of date.Representatives from the current Tranent pharmacies ndash Lloyds Pharmacy and Well Tranent, both on High Street ndash were present at the committee hearing and both claimed that they had already addressed any issues that were raised in the consultation and therefore problems raised by the CAR were no longer applicable.There was also a question over whether the premises planned for the new pharmacy at  Bridge Street would be large enough to support the planned two consultation rooms and dispensary area, which the committee felt raised the issue of whether appropriate confidentiality was possible.Letters of support for the pharmacy were submitted by Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council and ward councillor Kenny McLeod among others however, the committee felt that none of these letters ldquospecied needs which were currently not being met.Pharmacy applicant Niamh Morrison visited the community council to thank members for their support over the process and to assure them that she would be launching an appeal.She said: ldquoI am of course very disappointed.ldquoI really believe that this community needs this, and I have developed a real soft spot for the area.ldquoThe appeal process unfortunately wonrsquot be quick, it could take years.ldquoI just wanted to thank you all for the support that you have given us.The rejection comes not long after Tranent Medical Practice announced that it would be suspending advanced appointments due to a shortage of GPrsquos.Robert McNeill, a member of the community council, said: ldquoFrom a personal point of view, Irsquom very disappointed.ldquoTranent surgery is not unique in its problems and the pharmacy could have added extra services within the community.David Forrest, chairman of the community council added with regards the letter that the group had drafted to support the application: ldquoThe letters that we wrote came from the heart, we really feel that this was what was best for our community.ldquoWe are incredibly disappointed with the decision, and fully support Niamh in her appeal.ldquoWe will be writing to our local MP and MSP to register our frustration at the situation.ldquoThe decision is very short-sighted.The decision comes as planning permission in principle has been approved for  houses at Windygoul South, though the committee determined that both Lloyds and Well Tranent were able to increase capacity should ldquoproposed housebuilding occur locally.Ward councillor Kenny McLeod said: ldquoWith the new houses on their way, the town will need extra pharmacies and more GPs.ldquoIrsquom so disappointed that the pharmacy has been rejected, I really think we need one.

title: matt-kuchar-among-four-players-tied-scottish-open-lead-first-day
story: Kuchar shot an eight-under-par  in todays first round, leaving him tied with Frenchman Romain Wattel and Italian duo Edoardo Molinari and Nino Bertasio.Other big names who impressed were Swedens Henrik Stenton and Englishman Ian Poulter, who finished two shots behind the leaders, as did Richie Ramsay, who is the top-placed Scot after the first round.East Lothians Grant Forrest also had a fine showing, finishing with a four-under-par , the same total as four-time Major winner Rory McIlroy.Former Dunbar Grammar School pupil David Drysdale finished a shot further back but it also in good shape to make the cut with a similar round in tomorrows second day of play.

title: pictures-regiment-receives-historic-honour-parading-dunbar
story: Members of the public lined the streets in Dunbar on Saturday as a special presentation and parade took place to mark the historic moment involving the Lothians and Border Yeomanry.The regimentrsquos links with East Lothian date back to  with the formation of the East Lothian Yeomanry Cavalry.The Dunbar, Seton, Salton and Gford troops eventually disbanded and joined with other areas before reforming in  under the current name.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, East Lothian Councilrsquos Armed Forces Champion, conferred the Freedom of East Lothian to the Yeomanry, represented by Major Stuart Vine, in the shadow of Lauderdale House, the Regimentrsquos original home.Mr Goodfellow, who represents the North Berwick Coastal ward, said: ldquoAs well as being a landmark building on Dunbarrsquos High Street, Lauderdale House is the historic home of the Lothians and Border Yeomanry.ldquoIt is therefore appropriate that we are celebrating this occasion here in its shadow.ldquoThe Freedom of East Lothian is the highest honour our council can award.ldquoIt recognises those who play an important role here: those who represent our county and its values, contribute to the fabric of our civic society or who are integral to the history and tradition of East Lothian.ldquoIn granting the Freedom to the Lothians and Border Yeomanry today, the Regiment joins the Royal Scots Borderers st Battalion, renowned artist John Bellany and golf champion Catriona Matthew as worthy recipients of this rarely-bestowed tribute.ldquoLast weekend, our nation came together to commemorate Armed Services Day, which marks the important part that the Armed Services have played, and continue to play, in our society.ldquoToday we come together as a county to pay our particular thanks to the members of the Lothians and Border Yeomanry for the part it has played in East Lothian since its earliest roots as the East Lothian Yeomanry Cavalry in .ldquoIt is extraordinary to think that the regiment has represented East Lothian in every conflict since the Napoleonic Wars, including the Great War.Following the presentation, the regiment paraded along Dunbarrsquos High Street, saluting Mr Goodfellow outside the Town House, before continuing on to its war memorial outside Dunbar Parish Church on the townrsquos Queenrsquos Road for a rededication ceremony.Representatives from the council, serving and veteran members of the Armed Services community and their families, support organisations and crowds of well-wishers witnessed the occasion.Granting the Freedom of East Lothian to the regiment recognises the sacrices and service made by its members over the years, and reinforces the councilrsquos commitment to all armed services members living within the county.Major SJ Vine, Squadron Leader, ESquadron, The Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry, said the squadron was ldquotruly honoured to be given the Freedom of East Lothian.He added: ldquoThe day marks the reinvigoration of the strong partnership between the community and the squadron from which many of those serving, have served or represented through our long history and antecedent regiments live and work ndash we are grateful for the enduring support.ldquoIt is signicant and fitting that we are able to parade through Dunbar and also rededicate the war memorial in what is our spiritual home.ldquo[It was] a truly proud and memorable day and one which reconnects the lsquoCountyrsquos Regimentrsquo with the community whom we serve.The presentation and parade were part of a day of celebration of the regiment and Armed Services held in the town.A civic reception was held at the Town House for the Yeomanry and its supporters where a framed lsquoFreedom of East Lothianrsquo certicate was presented.The British Legion hosted a family event at its club for  people, while Dunbar Museum hosted a special one-day exhibition of the Yeomanryrsquos military treasures.

title: car-submerged-tide-north-berwick-beach
story: The incident, which took place on Sunday, required the assistance of the townrsquos RNLI, who had to tow the car out using their leboat tractor.The incident attracted plenty of attention, with many people stopping to take a look at the car being recovered.Eyewitness Derek Braid said: ldquoThe problem started when the owner of the car was recovering a RIB from the sea.ldquoThe car became stuck on the soft sand on the beach at the West Bay and the incoming tide engulfed the car.When the RNLI arrived, crew members attached a rope from the tractor to the car.After a number of attempts and plenty of pushing by the leboat crew and the other people nearby, the car was eventually successfully towed out of the water and taken to safety on the Elcho Green slipway.

title: degree-delight-ex-leuchie-chief
story: Mairi OrsquoKeefe was awarded a lsquoDegree of Doctor of the University, Honoris Causarsquo at a graduation ceremony in the Usher Hall in Edinburgh on Tuesday.She celebrated alongside Prue Leith, The Great British Bake Off judge and chancellor at Musselburgh-based QMU.Mairi is the former chief executive of Leuchie House, a respite care centre near North Berwick that provides care for those suffering from long-term neurological conditions and their families.She took over the helm at Leuchie in  when it was operated by the MS Society however, this was not her first experience in management as she has held ious airport manager and change manager roles.She helped save the centre from closure in  after setting up the lsquoSave Leuchiersquo campaign and building support for the centre.The campaign gained enough backing to allow Leuchie to become an independent charity.Over the next seven years, Mairi and her team secured pound. million in grants from trust funds and donations from members of the public, as well as support from the Scottish Government, delivering more than , respite nights.Mairi sat on cross-party groups in the Scottish Parliament, was vice-chair of the Health and Social Alliance Scotland and a member of the Governing Council for Edinburgh Chamber of Commerce.In  she was awarded lsquoCommunity Champion of the yearrsquo in STVrsquos lsquoFinding Scotlandrsquos Real Heroesrsquo awards. Two years later, she received an MBE for services to people with disabilities.Mairi has helped establish an official partnership with QMU, which has been in place since . The partnership has allowed for clinical and work placements, research and creative opportunities to be provided to many students, including nurses, film students, dietetics, physiotherapy and gastronomy.Mairi announced her retirement last year.Professor Petra Wend, principal and vice-chancellor of QMU, said: ldquoWe are delighted that our students had the opportunity to learn about the career of this former nursing and social care leader and to be inspired by her achievements and her compassion for others.ldquoWe are proud to recognise Mairi as a hard-working advocate for people living with disabilities across Scotland and beyond.ldquoWe celebrated her achievements as a leader and her success in integrating healthcare with respite services.

title: schoolteacher-recreates-law-primary-school-lego
story: The P pupils were invited to make their own creations to join supply teacher Malcolm Piriersquos recreation of the primary school at the Awesome Bricks event as it took pride of place at the exhibition.And Malcolm said he was delighted by the efforts of the youngsters, who came up with an array of designs for the weekend event.The opportunity was a chance for Malcolm, , to bring his passion for Lego to the classroom and inspire youngsters with what he hopes can become a valuable teaching resource in the future.An enthusiast since he was a young boy, Malcolm knows first-hand the impact the modelling bricks can have on children.When he was a nine-year-old living in Abu Dhabi, UAE, he took first place in a Lego competition organised to promote learning through the creative art and sending him and his family on atrip to Legoland in Billund, Denmark, where he became an honorary citizen.Nearly four decades later, Malcolm has brought his enthusiasm for Lego to schools where he has been working, and encouraged children at Law Primary to get involved when he was given the chance to take part in the exhibition at East Fortune.It is not the first time that he has captured youngstersrsquo imagination at the school with Lego and, during a stint there in , he amazed youngsters with some of the models created.And it was his knowledge of the school which inspired his model of the building, which he said had taken him a week of intensive work to put together.Malcolm told the Courier: ldquoIn previous times at the school, I spent time as a playground supervisor as well as in the classroom and knew the building well.ldquoI thought it would be a good model to recreate and people would recognise it.And his efforts impressed Jill Wareham, Law Primary Schoolrsquos headteacher.She said: ldquoWe were all really impressed by the Lego model of Law Primary School.It was very recognisable as our school ndash right down to the miniature Law in the playground.Supply teacher Malcolm is hoping to use his expertise with Lego to create future projects which could provide learning opportunities for youngsters.He said: ldquoIrsquom trying to focus on things from a dferent angle and will be looking to use Lego exclusively as a teaching resource and will work on developing activities and lessons on that basis.ldquoWhether I can make a viable business out of that is something Irsquoll be finding out soon.

title: please-don-39-t-ask-don-39-t-always-use-wheelchair
story: Laura Oliver was diagnosed with Functional Neurological Disorderaged .The -year-old, originally from Cornwall, has lived in Haddington for three years but feels people do not understand the condition, the symptoms of which include fatigue, loss of balance, memory problems and seizures.She said: ldquoIt is incredibly common [but] even within hospitals, the condition is not well advocated at all.ldquoI would be using a wheelchair about  per cent of the time. The rest of the time, I use a long cane because of my eyesight or my mobility scooter.ldquoI can get total paralysis and be stuck in bed for weeks at a time.On first finding out she had the condition, Laura said: ldquoI got very, very clumsy.ldquoAt first, I did not put it down to anything and just thought I was not very co-ordinated. Then I started to get fatigue and had to use a wheelchair.Other symptoms included a loss of sight, as well as the need to use catheters.Originally, doctors diagnosed Laura with multiple sclerosis.She said: ldquoI was then told it was part of a depressive illness and I would get better.ldquoThen I met Dr Stoneand he was that one that said FND. It is le-limiting but not le-threatening.Laura, who grew up wanting to be a nurse in the navy, told the Courier how receiving a diagnosis had actually helped open up a community where she could discuss the condition.However, she said not everyone was so understanding, with people often questioningshe truly had a condition.She said: ldquoI have had people say to me lsquoI saw you walking one day and the next minute you are in a wheelchairrsquo.ldquoOn another occasion, I have had somebody saying it was mental health. They would say it is all in my head and that I need to see a psychiatrist.But she was quick to praise the work of groups such as Our Community Kitchen, which tackles social isolation through bringing people together three days a week for a three-course meal, and outreach programme Friday Friends.Dawn Golder, executive director of FND Hope, which aims to promote awareness of FND and support for anyone affected by the condition, said: ldquoUnfortunately, FND whilst common, is still highly stigmatised and many healthcare and medical professionals still think it is all in the patientrsquos lsquoheadrsquo.ldquoI think the issue is in relation to historical names for FND.ldquoResearch has now proven that many people with FND do not have to have a psychological psychiatric element to their diagnosis.

title: construction-work-waste-incinerator-near-dunbar-now-complete
story: Final tests are being carried out at the energy recovery facilityat Oxwellmains, with low-carbon energy already being generated at the site, to the south-west of Dunbar.The completion of Viridorrsquos ERF marks the latest milestone in a project delivering a , tonne per year energy recovery facility to Scotland.A key part of the poundm investment by Viridor in Scotland, the ERF will ert non-recyclable waste from landfill in line with the Scottish Governmentrsquos ambitions and contribute to Scottish energy security.More than  contractors put in more than two-million man hours to the project, with more than  workers on site at its peak.Scott Reynolds, Dunbar ERF operations manager, said that the site had already started generating low-carbon energy for the national grid and, over the course of the coming year, would create MW of base-load low-carbon energy direct to the electricity grid.The energy generated ndash which, according to Viridor, is comparable to  wind turbines ndash is enough to continuously power , homes.Mr Reynolds said: ldquoViridor is pleased to be working with the Scottish local authorities and businesses to put non-recyclable waste to work.ldquoWith the construction phase of the project now complete, we are carrying out final plant testing as we process non-recyclable waste, using this as the fuel to create electricity.ldquoThe new facility includes a visitorsrsquo centre, where we look forward to welcoming interested groups to encourage the next generation to put the right stuff in the right bin.ldquoWe will be talking about recycling here at the plant because we want to ensure valuable recycling opportunities are not missed.ldquoThe waste which comes here should only be waste which cannot be recycled, allowing us to attach a purpose to it through energy recovery.The plant is constructed on , piles, or vertical foundations, upon which sit more than , tonnes of concrete and steel to support the processing equipment of the -metre-high building.The facility features two boilers, each processing  tonnes of waste each hour, and managed and controlled through km of pipework and km of cabling.Waste received at Dunbar ERF will include residual household waste from East Lothian Council, as well as the local authorities in North and South Lanarkshire, in addition to non-recyclable commercial collections from Edinburgh and the Lothians.

title: bernd-wiesberger-wins-scottish-open-play-off-drama
story: The Austrian held a two-shot lead going into todayrsquosfinal round.However, he needed to dig deep to take the title at The Renaissance Club after a play-off battle with Benjamin Hebert.Andrew Johnstonrsquos - took him to - for the tournament and set an early marker.Then, Wiesberger and Hebert traded the lead over the afternoon in what was a preview of the play-off.Wiesberger edged into the lead with two holes to go but a bogey on the th saw him drop back to -.Frenchman Hebert, who secured a spot at The Open through his performance in East Lothian, had already wrapped up his fourth round by that point and had the advantage of being able to sit back and watch how the other players handled the pressure.His final round  ndash a score matched by Johnston ndash gave him a good chance of winning the title.In the end, all eyes were on the par four th hole, with Wiesberger needing par to force a play-off.He took his time over the vital putt, which he sank to ensure the drama would continue.Seventy-two holes could not decide an outright winner, which meant the need to play the th hole again.In the first play-off, it looked like advantage Hebert after a fine second shot but Wiesberger secured par.Hebert had a putt to take the title but could not do it and had to settle for a par of his own to force a second play-off hole.The Frenchman had a second opportunity but again it was not to be and both men made their journey back to the th tee for a third play-off hole.Finally, Wiesberger wrapped up the victory in the fading light.Elsewhere, North Berwickrsquos Grant Forrest finished on an impressive - earlier in the day.A final round of  saw him pick up six birdies over the course with two bogeys along the way.The score was good enough for a tie of rd, one position behind last yearrsquos winner Brandon Stone and Rory McIlroy.He was East Lothianrsquos last representative, with David Drysdale cut after the third round yesterday .The former Dunbar Grammar School pupil scored  in his third round, which saw him finish the tournament on - alongside Englandrsquos Ashley Chesters.

title: coastguard-called-dinghy-runs-aground
story: The volunteer teams were called out at about .pm after off-duty coastguard and RNLI personnel spotted the wooden dinghy near Dunbarrsquos swimming pool.Crew from the townrsquos RNLI in-shore leboat came ashore to the dinghy and found no signs of recent occupancy.It was then taken under tow back to the nearby harbour.A spokesman for Dunbar Coastguard, who were joined at the scene by colleagues from North Berwick, said: ldquoThe name lsquoTommy rsquo is written on the side of the dinghy and efforts by the Coastguard to trace the owners have so far been unsuccessful.ldquoIf you recognise the dinghy or know of a vessel named lsquoTommy rsquo, please contact the Aberdeen Coastguard Operations Centreon   quoting incident number .ldquoIf you see someone in dficulty or something you are concerned about on the shoreline, beaches, clfs, mud or water, call  immediately and ask for the Coastguard.

title: haddingtons-swimming-pool-re-open-earlier-expected
story: The facilities have been undergoing a refurbishment and had initially been expected to re-open at the end of June, but that was later pushed back to next Saturday .However, it has now been announced that the pool will now re-open on Monday at am.Bill Axon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, which runs the centre on behalf of East Lothian Council, said: ldquoThese works will completely enhance the visitor experience for all customers and have transformed the pool into a bright and modern community asset which can only benefit the population of Haddington and beyond.Tom Reid, East Lothian Councils head of infrastructure, added: ldquoThis is an excellent example of partnership working and we are delighted with the outcome, which we know will be greatly appreciated by both customers and staff alike.

title: metal-detecting-fan-hailed-hero-finding-wedding-ring-fell-sea
story: Toby Binnian, from Newbyth ndash between Tyninghame and Whitekirk ndash and Holly Clement got married on Saturday.But the ringplunged into the waters off Tyninghame during a swim the very next day.Devastated, Holly sent a social media SOS to Dean Houston after she discovered the existence of East Lothian Metal Detecting Club.And when Dean kindly agreed to sweep the wet sand at Tyninghame on Monday morning with his metal detector when the tide was out, he surprised even himself when he found what he described as a ldquoneedle in a haystack.Holly, who grew up in Haddington, said it had been an eventful start to married le but they were delighted to once again be in possession of the cherished band.She said: ldquoToby was so upset that he lost it and it is more relief for him than anything ."Friends and family were devastated for him and we are just so happy to get the ring back.PE teacher Toby, , and dentist Holly, , first met while at school at Edinburgh Academy and have been together for  years.They were married at the Log Cabin at Ravensheugh on Saturday and decided to mark their first full day as husband and we with a swim at nearby Tyninghame.Holly recalled: ldquoAll our friends arrived and we were on the beach going to go for a swim."We debated about whether to keep the ring on or off and we thought because it was quite a snug fit that it would be fine.ldquoToby went out for a swim while we were jumping through the waves.ldquoI donrsquot know what possessed him but someone asked himthe ring was OK and he tested it to see whether it would go over his knuckle.ldquoThen, all of a sudden, it went plop into the water and he was panicking.ldquoIt is a palladium ring and not a very bright white colour, so it disappeared into the murky waters and we were chest high in the water.Amongst the panic, the couple, who now live in York, decided to bring in outside help.A search of Facebook brought up the newly-formed East Lothian Metal Detecting Club.Holly said: ldquoWe just said: lsquoPlease help, my idiot new husband has dropped his ring in the sea.rsquoShe remained ldquoblindly optimistic of being reunited with the ring because they had a rough idea where it had fallen into the water.Within an hour, the group got in touch and, after a check of tide times, arrived at the beach on Monday morning.Holly said: ldquoI had slightly given up hope and walked up to sit with family on the headland and stay out of the way.ldquoI just heard lots of cheering and we all sprinted down to check it was real.Dean, from the local metal detecting club, was delighted to be able to help and within an hour had tracked down the ring in the wet sand.The Dunbar resident thought it would be like finding ldquoa needle in a haystack and added: ldquoI was expecting an area of a couple of feet by a couple of feet but it was more like  or  feet square that they gave me.Dean was given a helping hand by his black Labrador Roxy.He said: ldquoMy dog was digging holes and I just walked over and the metal detector beeped.ldquoThey all started running up and giving me hugs, which is a bit embarrassing when you donrsquot know them!ldquoThen they were all trying to phone Toby.Holly said she was forever thankful to Dean, adding: ldquoHe was just so lovely, unassuming and he was just great.ldquoToby is a little bit scared and does not know whether to keep the ring on or take it off!ldquoHe is wearing it just now but he is thinking about getting it resized.Anyone interested in finding out more about the metal detecting club should email elmdclub@yahoo or search for East Lothian Metal Detecting Club on Facebook.

title: teenager-spat-bus-driver-argument-ticket
story: Nathan Cook spat on bus employee Colin Dickson during an altercation while the vehicle was on the townrsquos High Street last year.Cook, , had attempted to buy a ticket which was not for sale at that time and proceeded to get into a row with the driver.During the argument, Cook got close to the partition glass that separates the driver from the public and spat at him.Cook appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Wednesday where he pleaded guilty to the assault on Mr Dickson.Prosecutor Clare Kennedy said that Mr Dickson was driving the public bus on Tranent High Street at about .pm on April  last year.Ms Kennedy said: ldquoMr Cook got on the bus and asked for a ticket which could not be produced at that time of day.ldquoThe driver told Mr Cook of this and an argument between them [broke out] and came to an end and Mr Cook sat down and Mr Dickson carried on the bus route.ldquoBut they began arguing again as the bus pulled up to a stop on Tranent High Street. Mr Cook put his face up to the glass and spat through the glass and [the spit] landed on [the driverrsquos] arm.Sherf Pamela Bowman told Cook: ldquoThis was a bad, bad thing to do. The bus driver was only doing his job.Sherf Bowman deferred sentence to July next year for Cook, from Edinburgh, to be of good behaviour.Cook admitted assaulting Colin Dickson by spitting on his body on April  last year.

title: tim-39-s-tales-happy-ending-last-mistreated-women
story: AGNES Blakelived in Haddington in the early s. She was regarded as an lsquoincomerrsquo, however, as she was born at Bolton, a couple of miles away, where she likely spent much of her childhood. When and how she came to Haddington I cannot say, or what her childhood was like, but it seems clear she was poor and for her, le was a struggle.She seems to have found companionship with Elizabeth Golight, who was Haddington born and bred. Perhaps they were neighbours in Haddington. Whatever their circumstances, they drew the attention of others and found themselves in court.This is how they came to the attention of another woman from another century: Ros Parkyn. She sadly died only a few weeks ago, but her le was full of stories and love for people, and she had an especially sharp eye for injustice and empathy for people unfairly treated or judged.Ros was browsing in the John Gray Centre in  and noticed a temporary display of mixed objects and records from their collections. There was a volume of court records laid open for perusal and Ros peered at the entries.The entries hadnrsquot been transcribed but she could just make out that they were accounts of the trials of two women who lived in Haddington in . The th-century handwriting, with its dferent spelling, was very dficult to read in the display case, and so Ros asked the staffit was possible to take the document from the case.A friendly and helpful staff member obliged, then sat down with Ros and assisted her to transcribe the writing. It wasnrsquot easy sometimes they couldnrsquot decipher a word at all, while others seemed to be spelt dferently at dferent times. But gradually, as Ros wrote the words down, she became introduced to Agnes and Elizabeth.There were accounts of others too, but she was particularly taken with the account of these two women, the language used to describe them, and the cruel punishments they suffered.In the account, Agnesrsquos name is spelt in three dferent ways, but was likely Blake or Black.Here is the transcription Ros made:January Agnes Blaik Indweller in Haddington born in the parish of Boulton and Elizabeth Golight, daughter to William Golight, born in this parish being both accused and imprisoned as guilty of lewdness and uncleanliness with many dferent persons. Elizabeth Golight confesses that since Michaelmas last she has been guilty of uncleanliness with several persons and Agnes Blaikie confesses she was formerly convict of uncleanliness and that she was a bad woman ndash But not of late. But acknowledges she lives in a house alone and that there has been dragoons with her in the house. Which being considered by the Magistrates they find Elizabeth Golight is a vicious strumpet and to their certain information Agnes Blaik is a vicious lewd woman. And therefore they ordain both the said Elizabeth Golight and Agnes Blaik be taken to the cross Friday next with the officers and Hangman and there to stand sometime with a paper or sack of theirhellip donating their crime and thereafter be conveyed tohellip with beat of the drum and to be banished forever out of the borough with certicationever they or either one of themto or be seen in this burgh they shall be whipped by the hangman.Signed Andrew Dixon, George Cunningham, Bailies.But it seems the harsh punishment did not prevent them from ing to the town, for Ros came across another two entries:th May Appeared with Janet Golight her mother Elizabeth for repeating acts of lewdness and stealing from Robina Mucklersquos shop. Both found guilty and sent to the House of Correction in Edinburgh to be kept at hard work for  years. Should be whipped by the hangman and burnt on the cheek.th June Agnes Black ed to buy a gown for herself and so was sentenced to be whipped through the town and banished.Ros later sent me her transcriptions, saying: ldquoI love the way Agnes confessed she lsquowas a bad woman ndash but not of latersquo. It rings out over the centuries. And I have a definite dislike for the bailies pronouncing on the lsquovicious strumpetrsquo and the lsquovicious lewd womanrsquo, particularly as there is no mention of any man being named, despite the men being lsquoto their certain informationrsquo!Ros had emailed me the transcription in January  and wrote to me: ldquoI thought it was a tale worth telling and you could weave your magic on it and perhaps find a happy ending.To my regret, I only came across this email last week, as it had somehow remained unopened in my inbox for over two years. I admit to being technically useless on computer matters!But a happy ending  Itrsquos clear both Agnes and Elizabeth had very harsh lives, and on the surface there seems little scope for a truly happy ending.The description of them is misogynistic and full of double standards, as Ros pointed out.So what were these women really like  The writer tries to paint a picture of awful human beings, but the image of poor Agnes secretly creeping back into town, no doubt in a state of desperation, to ldquobuy herself a gown and then being whipped as a punishment gives a dferent story. The punishments for both women are barbaric and utterly unjust.Then I realised that there was a happy ending. That happy ending was in late , when Ros walked into the John Gray Centre and found out about Agnes and Elizabeth. She read the account with human understanding and saw through the prejudice to glimpse at the women themselves and understand just how wrongly they had been treated and judged. And so she spoke up for them and gave them a place in history, while turning the judgment on their accusers.Thatrsquos a happy ending I know Ros would have liked.

title: east-lothian-surfer-features-new-advert-carling
story: The five surfers ndash aged between  and  ndash took on the waves for a national advertising campaign for the beer giant called lsquoMade Localrsquo.Retired roofer Ian McKay, from Whitekirk, was joined by Jason Burnett, Douglas Brown and Dee Ripol, all from Edinburgh, with filming taking place over two days nearly two years ago. Rod Wallace was also present.A film crew set up base for the advert, which can be viewed online, at Pease Bay, about two miles from the East Lothian county boundary, with impressive surfing conditions helping to create a stunning advert.Jason, , told the Courier: ldquoWe were approached by Carling, who found us through social media.ldquoThey were impressed by how wersquore making it where wersquore from ndash my surfboard-making business for the local community in particular struck a chord. Our story inspired Carling to feature us in its Made Local advert with the aim of encouraging more people to follow their passions in their local area.ldquoThe Made Local Fund is Carlingrsquos multi-million-pound commitment over the next three years to those things that matter most to local communities, just like us and our surfing.ldquoCarling have recently supported me in providing funding for the materials needed to hand craft and design some surfboards which will be donated to the Scottish Surfing Federation.ldquoThese bespoke surfboards will be provided free to people who want to try surfing for the first time.Ian, , has been surfing with friends for more than  years, with the sport gaining popularity across Scotland.And while surfing hot spots include Hawaii, Calornia and Australiarsquos Gold Coast, East Lothian was proving popular as well.Jason, who makes surfboards, said the county was an ideal place for them to get into the water.He said: ldquoCold water surfing in East Lothian is hardcore!ldquoIn winter the waves are big, the weather is cold and the sea is colder, but we donrsquot let that put us off ndash we donrsquot care how cold it is.ldquoWersquore proud to surf in all weathers and all year round. Nothing stops us.ldquoSurfing these waters is also a big social thing for us too.ldquoThe friendships we have forged through years of surfing in these freezing cold waters still stand strong today.ldquoWe have surfed all over the world, but no matter where the sport has taken us, coming back to home waters is where our hearts lie.ldquoThe local beaches along the East Lothian coastline are really special and have some of the most stunning scenery in the world.The video can be viewed by going to Carlingrsquos YouTube page.
