title: scottish-open-renaissance-club-attracts-record-attendance
story: Nearly , people attended the Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open while the competition, which was played at The Renaissance Club, also produced its lowest score to par.Bernd Wiesberger was crowned the winner following three play-off holes at the course, near Dirleton.He carded  under ndash which was matched by Benjamin Hebert and was the lowest score to par since the competition began in .Early figures suggest , attended the competition, up by nearly , from last yearrsquos tournament at Gullane Golf Club.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said that the tournament had proven ldquoa great success, with analysis to be carried out to look at its economic benefits.She said: ldquoThe Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open was a great success, with record attendance figures of almost , who enjoyed world-class golf at The Renaissance Club.ldquoThe economic boost to East Lothian of this tournament and the forthcoming Aberdeen Standard Investments Ladies Scottish Open will be independently assessed and we look forward to seeing the results of that assessment later this year.ldquoIt was also a successful event for the many local food and drink suppliers who won contracts to supply the event.Neil Christison, VisitScotland regional director, felt the eventrsquos success was another great advert for the county as a golfing destination.He said: ldquoThe Scottish Open at The Renaissance Club was a great success, attracting visitors from across the world and showcasing East Lothian as a top destination for international events to a global audience.ldquoAnd there is still more to come for East Lothian this summer, with Ladies Scottish Open and Scottish Senior Open taking place in the region in the coming weeks.ldquoThe staging of these high-profile sporting events has an immense impact on tourism in East Lothian and surrounding areas, attracting golf fans from across Scotland and beyond.ldquoWith its range of  courses, high-quality accommodation, food and drink, and visitor attractions, East Lothian really does live up to its name as Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast.ldquoGolf is a vital part of the visitor economy, with the ripple effect felt in shops, hotels, restaurants and a wide iety of other businesses across the region.ldquoGolf tourism is worth poundm to the country annually ndash and around pound.million to East Lothian alone.Cast a great lightGael Pollitt, chair of Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast, felt that the event had cast the county in a great light.He said: ldquoThere is no doubt that the hosting of the ASI Scottish Open on Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast again showed East Lothian to be a golfing Mecca and the live TV streaming of the championship throughout the world will surely boost interest in all the county has to offer.ldquoDuring commentary and written reports there were frequent references made to the wide range of golf courses and the ersity of accommodation options available.ldquoOn our stand in the championship village, it was very encouraging to hear the comments from visitors who had travelled considerable distances of their desire toand play courses that they had not previously appreciated, as well as visit the many other tourist attractions in East Lothian.ldquoIn three weeksrsquo time, it is the turn of the ladies to compete on Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast, when again many of the top players in the world will be present.North Berwick Coastal ward councillors Jim Goodfellow and Jeremy Findlay also felt the event had gone well.Mr Goodfellow said: ldquoThe Scottish Open has been another success for East Lothian tourism and has brought positive worldwide exposure for the county and economic benefit for local businesses.ldquoWe were lucky with the weather and the use of The Renaissance course minimising local traffic disruption.ldquoThe credit for the smooth running of the event must go to our council officers and the event organisers.Mr Findlay added: ldquoIt was a great event for East Lothian and showcases Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast, which is now the premier golfing location in Scotland.Councillor Jane Henderson, a ward colleague, agreed that the event appeared to have gone smoothly but she questioned what impact it had had on local businesses over the four days.The councillor noted that a number of businesses were very quiet during the tournament but acknowledged that the success of the competition could leave a positive long-term impact.She said: ldquoYou have to look at both sides and that is definitely my stance.ldquoIn the shorter term, people have bills and rent to pay and are running businesses.ldquoIt is alright for tourism and economic development to say the long-term impact will pay off in East Lothian.Businesses painted a mixed picture when it came to the impact of the tournament.Chris Hansen, owner of The Open Arms in Dirleton, was among those enjoying a fruitful week.He said: ldquoIt was a good week. The place was maybe a little bit quieter during the day when it was centred on the golf course.ldquoIn general, we were quite lucky with the weather.Gullanersquos Co-op store was also affected by the tournament, with traffic encouraged to avoid the village.Greg Millar, store manager, said: ldquoWe actually did better than what I thought we would but didnrsquot do as well as the business thought we would,that makes sense.ldquoIt could have been a lot betterthe traffic was erted through Gullane.Meanwhile, Tricia Johnstone, of Fenton Barns Farm Shop and Cafe, felt the event had a detrimental impact on their business.She said: ldquoIt damages business more than increases it.ldquoA lot of people just stay away.But Carol Millar, from The Golfers Rest on North Berwick High Street, said the pub was ldquobusy, adding: ldquoOn Friday and Saturday it was absolutely crazy. I donrsquot knowit is because we are called The Golfers Rest but it was quite busy.Tom Drysdale, chairman of Gullane Area Community Council, which also covers Dirleton, said the impact in terms of flow of people and traffic through the village was ldquonot very signicant.He said: ldquoI went on Saturday and Sunday and there was a wonderful atmosphere. I think it was a very good thing for the area.ldquoI think it would be fair to say it did not have a major impact on the village of Dirleton itself but, speaking as a community council for the other areas, it was a big event for us and brought a tremendous number of visitors to the area and I think that has a long-term legacy.

title: provost-flies-flag-east-lothian-festival-france
story: John McMillan, Provost of East Lothian, was carrying the Haddington flag through Aubigny-sur-Nere on Sunday afternoon during a parade in the Franco-Scottish Festival.The Haddington and Lammermuir ward councillor was flanked by his son Douglas and brother Jim, who were carrying the town keys.Mr McMillan is visiting the town on a family holiday and was joined there by Haddington Pipe Band.He the Courier: ldquoIt was quite a long parade and I thought I really should be flying the flag.ldquoEverybody in the pipe band played tremendously over the weekend.ldquoI am here on holiday but was asked to open the festival and the flag was here.ldquoI had been given the keys to the town on Friday evening at a formal ceremony and it was a real honour to march behind the pipe band as they were leading the parade.Liz McDougall, the pipe band quartermaster, carried the flag at the morning ceremony at the war memorial alongside the townrsquos veterans.A copy of last weekrsquos Courier ndash wrapped in tartan and red, white and blue ribbon ndash was also presented to the townrsquos archive.A link between the East Lothian town and Aubigny, which is between Orleans and Bourges in central France, dates back to .Residents of each town have regularly made the trip to their counterparts.The twinning links are evident throughout Haddington, with a sign outside Haddington Corn Exchange bearing the street name Place drsquoAubigny, and the townrsquos leisure centre also named after the French settlement.Mr McMillan explained the importance of the relationship between the two countries and the two towns.He said: ldquoI think the French are aware of the Auld Alliance but in Aubigny it is particularly alive and remembered with links to the Hundred Yearsrsquo War, when a Scottish lord rescued the town from the English and gave wood to rebuild the town.

title: bid-name-new-sports-pavilion-39-unofficial-mayor-north-berwick-39
story: Labour Party stalwart and former vice-chairman of Heart of Midlothian FC Pilmar Smith passed away in November last year.Now, plans are being drawn up to pay tribute to Mr Smith, who was , including the idea of a plaque in his honour at a new sports pavilion.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, who represents North Berwick, said: ldquoThere has been a move within the town to have some sort of commemorative something around the town.ldquoThe proposal at the moment is that there is a new sports pitch being built up at the new housing by the high school.ldquoThere is to be a pavilion there and the proposal is we name it the Pilmar Smith Pavilion and a plaque goes up to that effect.ldquoIt would probably mention his connections with football over the years and North Berwick.The pitch, which is to the west of Law Primary School, is not yet playable, with the new surface needing time to bed in..However, it is expected to open later this year, with planning permission already in place for the pavilion.East Lothian Council is looking to appoint a contractor for the pavilion, with work expected to start in November and be complete by spring next year.Mr Smith was raised in Edinburgh and spent several decades as a bookmaker.A Hearts fan all his le, he became vice-chairman of the Tynecastle club in , during which time they twice finished as runners-up in the Scottish Football League Premier Division.He held the position for  years before stepping down following a change of ownership.Mr Smith was chairman of East Lothian Constituency Labour Party until about  and spent more than a decade as chairman of Lothian Buses.Mr Goodfellow previously expressed his gratitude to Mr Smith in helping him to be elected as the first-ever Labour councillor for the area.He said: ldquoIt would be an excellent tribute to someone who contributed a lot to North Berwick during his time here.Judy Lockhart, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, gave her backing to the idea.She told the Courier: ldquoThe community council were very saddened to hear of the passing of Pilmar Smith in November last year.ldquoPilmar had lived in North Berwick for around  years and was as well-known as he was well loved.ldquoOne can only imagine how long it took Pilmar to walk from one end of High Street to the other when you consider that almost every person he passed would stop him for a lsquoquick chatrsquo!ldquoFollowing requests from residents, the community council agreed that something was required to commemorate Pilmar and local elected councillor Jim Goodfellow suggested that the new football pavilion might be the ideal site.ldquoGiven that Pilmar was a lelong fan of Hearts Football Club, where he also served as a director and vice-chairman for more than a decade, this seemed a fitting tribute.ldquoThe community council have since allocated funding to purchase a plaque and, with great fondness, look forward to naming the new football pavilion the lsquoPilmar Smith Pavilionrsquo in his memory.

title: tranent-minister-rubs-shoulders-royalty-garden-party-palace-holyroodhouse
story: The Rev Erica Wishart, minister at Tranent Parish Church, was thrilled to be invited to the royal garden party in Edinburgh this year after being nominated by Michael Williams, Lord Lieutenant of East Lothian.She said: ldquoIt was a real privilege to be there, in the presence of Her Majesty the Queen along with Prince Andrew, Prince Edward and Princess Anne. My husband, the Rev Bill Wishart [minister at St Martinrsquos Parish Church in the Magdalene area of Edinburgh], came with me as my lsquoplus onersquo and we had a lovely afternoon walking around the gardens of Holyroodhouse in the sunshine.ldquoWe couldnrsquot get near enough to see the royal family close up, but we did manage to photograph the Queen from afar as she paused on the steps for the national anthem it was easy to spot her as she was wearing a bright salmon pink coat and hat.The royal family hosts four garden parties a year ndash three at Buckingham Palace and one at the Palace of Holyroodhouse ndash with more than , people attending in total. They are designed to recognise and reward the public service of the attendees.Erica added: ldquoThere were a few bands playing music in dferent parts of the gardens, which added atmosphere to the event.ldquoWe enjoyed the tea, sandwiches and cakes in the tea tent: I had been told to expect tiny ones but actually they were a decent size.There were cucumber sandwiches ndash of course! ndash and the egg sandwiches had mint leaves in them which gave an unusual taste, quite refreshing. We also had fruit tarts, Victoria sponge and macaroons, all very tasty.ldquoYou couldnrsquot miss the royal tea tent ndash it was the one with the crown on top ndash but we couldnrsquot get near it, the crowds were so big.ldquoIt was fun wandering around seeing all the dferent outfits, unorms and hats. Someone asked uswe had met anyone of note and I replied: lsquoYes, Billrsquos aunty Isabelle and her pal Dot!rsquo They were the first familiar faces we saw in the crowd.ldquoThatrsquos one of the good things about the garden party: people of all ages, from all walks of le are invited, so therersquos a feeling of inclusivity.ldquoIt was a grand day out and I have written to the Lord Lieutenant to thank him for nominating me to attend on behalf of Tranent Parish Church.

title: jennifer-maciver-positive-pathway-parenthood
story: For some, surrogacy ndashwhen a woman carries and gives birth to a baby for another person or couple ndashis the only option.The number of people applying to the courts to be formally recognised as the parents of a child following a surrogacy arrangement has increased across the UK in recent years reflecting a welcome change in societyrsquos views on the lsquotraditionalrsquo family.Jenner Maciver, head of family law at law firm Gillespie Macandrew welcomes a review of the existing legal framework around surrogacy.ldquoItrsquos very much a live and current issue and we are pleased to see the Scottish Law Commission and Law Commission of England and Wales have been jointly appraising existing legislation and have published proposals for consultation. The current law around surrogacy is outdated and doesnrsquot reflect modern medical advances or changes in social attitudes. Surrogacy is a particularly sensitive and emotionally demanding process for everyone involved so we welcome anything which simplies or modernises the legislation. A draft report is anticipated, followed by draft legislation by  but their proposals offer a clear indication about the recommended direction of travel, she says.Parental ordersCurrently, the surrogate, and her spouse ndash she has one ndash are the legal parents of the child at birth and their names are noted on the birth certicate. The intended parents must make an application to the court for a parental order to be recognised as the childrsquos parents, with the legal rights and responsibilities this entails. This can take around six months to process which she points out can pose several potential problems. The first is that while the intended parents are socially and psychologically the parents, that doesnrsquot match the legal position, which can cause identity problems. On the flip side, the surrogate doesnrsquot normally view herself as the childrsquos mother, but the law does. Secondly,the child needs medical care during the first six months of their le the intended parents will likely not have any legal standing to take medical decisions about the young child in their care, which is not on any view a good situation for the child.ldquoAt the moment there is a considerable gap between peoplersquos expectations and the law and signicant potential for misunderstandings. This is not a positive environment in which to welcome a child and we are pleased to see this being tackled as part of the review, says Maciver.She explains that the Law Commissionsrsquo lsquonew pathwayrsquo will have several positive outcomes: it will allow intended parents to become the legal parents from birth in some cases remove of the need for a genetic link between the intended parents and the child in some cases establish a new regulator for surrogacy create a register to allow those born of surrogacy arrangements to access information and for international surrogacy arrangements help those who have a child abroad to bring their child back to the UK with less red tape.The new framework, she says will set out proactive measures including ndashintroducing pre-conception safeguards that are built in before the baby is conceived to help to avoid problems later in the process. ldquoThe proposal is that before the child is conceived there must be a written agreement between the surrogate and the parent, an independent assessment of the childrsquos welfare, the intended parents and the surrogate are all bound to take independent legal advice so that they understand the process, they are all medically screened and criminal checks are carried out, she explains.The intended parents and the surrogate are also required to go to implications counselling to help establish the foundation for an appropriate and positive relationship.Which all sounds like an onerous process ndashbut itrsquos one which Maciver believes will actually signicantly enhance the current situation. ldquoItrsquos more proactive and sees the introduction of meaningful safeguards ndashwhich will hopefully reduce the problems that can sometimes arise after the birth of a child and provide clarity for those entering into a surrogacy arrangement exactly whatrsquos expected of them.The overseas optionOwing to the restrictions on commercial surrogacy in the UK and the dficulty in finding willing surrogates some people choose to go to countries where commercial surrogacy is legally possible ndashwhich often leads to further complications when trying to bring the baby back to the UK.Overseas situations, she says, account for approximately half of surrogacies and they will still have to apply for a parental order, which is also getting an overhaul. For example, currently the intended parents have to apply for that within six months of the child being born, which is a relatively narrow window. The proposal is remove that time limit. They are also proposing changes to make it easier and quicker to get a passport or visa to bring the child to live with them in Scotland. Unlike other areas of family law in Scotland, , surrogacy is an area that has seen cultural attitudes change faster than legislation and Maciver believes that the Law Commissionsrsquo proposals are welcome, though not perfect.While commercial surrogacy is banned, reasonable payments are allowed, which leads to grey areas which the proposals donrsquot yet address, for example, what is reasonable and what strays into lsquopaymentrsquo ldquoThe law in this instance is very dficult to apply, says Maciver. If the payment is higher than reasonably anticipated what options does the court have  There has so far been no refusal of a parental order based on the level of payment but itrsquos probably the most contentious area in the consultation. Itrsquos one in which people hold strong opposing views and so the Law Commissions have canvassed opinion about how these limitations should be set and enforced.Single parentsIn the meantime, though she is encouraged by the fact that in January the law was changed following a challenge to the Human Rights Act  meaning that single parents can now apply for a parental order. ldquoThis was the single most urgent issue: previously only married couples, civil partners, cohabitants or people in other enduring relationships could apply.And the future  Maciver says that there are dfering views about the best route forward ndashand of course the proposed changes are still at consultation stage. But she believes that the new pathwayis long overdue and will have very positive effect, improving the way that surrogacy works and better protecting the interests of surrogates, intended parents and ultimately the children involved.Which is a community whose numbers are fast increasing.Jenner Maciver, is head of family law at law firm Gillespie Macandrew, whocombine specialist, practical advice with a responsive, supportive and discrete service.For more information abouthow Gillespie Macandrew can help please visitwww.gillespiemacandrew

title: first-look-haddingtons-newly-refurbished-swimming-pool
story: Work got under way at the pool and health suite within the townrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre in April and ndash after a delay ndash the pool is due to re-open on Monday.Essential maintenance and interior deacutecor works have been carried out at the sports centre, off Mill Wynd, over several weeks.During the work, the two pools were drained, with a new light, bright ceiling covering the outdated wood cladding.New lighting has also been installed while the locker rooms have also been given a facelt and tiles have been given a thorough clean.The new-look pool was revealed to enjoyleisure members and politicians on Friday afternoon.The facility is one of East Lothianrsquos original sports centres and originally opened its doors as Haddington Swimming Pool in September .The much-loved site consists of a four-lane swimming pool and East Lothianrsquos only dedicated infant pool.Before the temporary closure, the facility welcomed about , bathers to the pool each week for swimming lessons, AquaFit classes, swimming club training, school and public use.

title: nurse-wanted-raasay-scottish-island-offers-39-shift-lifestyle-39
story: But Raasay, home to a population of around , has been without any resident medical cover for the past  years.Now, after a long campaign, islanders hope things are about to change as NHS Highland launches a recruitment drive today aimed at attracting a community nurse to live and work on the beauty spot.The island has no GP surgery and its last resident nurse retired a decade ago.She was replaced on a rota basis Monday to Friday by three district nurses who travel out from Portree, a -minute ferry ride away on the neighbouring Isle of Skye.: New Zealands carers will soon be earning up to pound a week- we should think about paying the sameThe only other medical cover is a GP surgery once a week on Wednesday morning when a family doctors sails out from Skye, but the situation has left residents on Raasay without any out-of-hours provision.In July , islanders launched a campaign for a resident nurse to be re-instated.A previous recruitment attempt by NHS Highland in December  failed, but this time the health board is hopeful of attracting candidates keen for a change in lestyle.The latest attempt follows a report in May  by Professor Sir Lewis Ritchie into out of hours care in Skye, Raasay and South West Ross, which emphasised the need for equal access to services even where population numbers are relatively small.His report has underpinned a new drive to turn the area into a centre of excellence for remote and rural healthcare - a factor which the health board hopes will also help to lure prospective candidates.Kate Earnshaw, district manager for NHS Skye, Lochalsh and Wester Ross, said: "This is an exciting opportunity for a suitably qualied and experienced nurse to join the Community Nursing Team and make a real dference to healthcare provision on Raasay."We hope this opening will appeal to candidates looking for a real sht in lestyle. Raasay is a wonderful place to live and work and we look forward to attracting lots of applications."The Band  post is permanent, can be full-time or part-time, and comes with a salary of pound, to pound,.: poundk bill for pest control at Glasgows superhospitalHe or she would be the first clinician on scene in the event of an emergency on the island, would be required to provide on-call nursing cover, and would be the main point of contact on the island for the Skye-based GPs and rural medics at the MacKinnon Memorial Hospital in Broadford, on Skye.The role promises "considerable autonomy" as Raasays nurse will be responsible for assessing, planning, implementing and reviewing the islands healthcare needs.NHS Highland said it is seeking "qualied, confident, competent and experienced" candidates who must be "adaptable and resourceful, working without a hospital or GP at hand".Up to date clinical knowledge and skills are required, as is a desire to work in a remote, rural setting.The health board hopes to be able to hire more than one nurse for the island.A spokeswoman said: "The post holder would have a lot of iety in their job every day is likely to be dferent as they would be dealing with patients from young children to the elderly."In addition to the professional challenges of working predominantly on their own, the remote location could present some challenges to everyday le, such as transport."For the community, the presence of resident nurse cover is greatly anticipated and will bring reassurance."Raasay is a wonderful place to work and live and to bring up a family. There is low crime, low pollution, amazing scenery and wildle."The community nurse is a highly respected member of the community."It has a vibrant community, entertaining year round visitors, a well-stocked community shop, post office, community hall, and an excellent primary school."Its within easy community distance to Portree on Skye."The Highlands and Islands have also been named as the happiest place to live in Scotland, according to the latest Bank of Scotland Happiness Index."Those living in the region highlighted the natural environment and a strong sense of community as key."The closing date for applications is August .: Meet the Scot who was the first person in the world to test salbutamol  years ago - and almost diedAnne Gillies, chair of Raasay Community Council, said: ldquoA resident nurse on Raasay will be a huge boost to the community."It will make an enormous dference, particularly to families with young children and our elderly population. Wersquore all very happy at the prospect of having a nursing presence on the island again.

Open seven days a week from am ndash .pm, visitors can enjoy hot and cold drinks and snacks.With beauty galore all year round, Kailzie Gardens has become a popular destination for weddings, both for religious and civil ceremonies. Offering a glorious location to tie the knot, they also provide flexibility in conjunction with the restaurant to host any size of gathering, able to accommodate the smallest or the largest of marquees. The chef can sit with couples and help organise a tasting of dishes and some of the finer details.For visitors coming from further afield planning a short break in the Scottish Borders, Kailzie Gardens can provide accommodation via their self-catering cottage, which sleeps six, and bunkhouse sleeping up to  people.To find out more about visiting the gardens or planning a wedding, visitwww.kailziegardensor call   .--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The Devilrsquos Porridge MuseumThe Devilrsquos Porridge Museum is a  star, award winning museum.Located in Dumfries and Galloway, it tells the story of the greatest munitions factory in World War One.It spanned an area nine-miles long and two-miles wide and contained a state of the art factory along with  miles of railway track,  stations, two towns, a power station, two cinemas, hospitals, a dentists, a maternity unit and schools., people worked here, , of them women.They mixed the devilrsquos porridge, which is a nickname for cordite, a propellant which was included within every single bullet and shell used in the First World War One.More than half of all the cordite used by the British armed forces was produced at this Anglo-Scottish site.People came from around the Empire to add their expertise: South African explosives experts, Australian chemists and Canadian engineers.They left their mark on the local area in the street names of Eastriggssuch as Vancouver Avenue and Delhi Road.This had led to Eastriggs being known as lsquothe Commonwealth village.rsquoThe Gretna girls had a dficult le: they worked with chemicals which caused their teeth to fall out, which discoloured their skin and caused them to feint from the fumes. Some young women suffered worse fates: an explosion killed one local girl, others lost arms and fingers or were severely burned due to the fires which could break out. Their work and leisure lives were strictly monitored: everything came under the official secrets act and over  members of the Womenrsquos Police Service monitored their movements and morals!The museum is set across two floors with interactive displays including films, games and oral testimonies of people from World War One and Two. There is so much military history in this part of Scotland that it has been named lsquoThe Solway Military Coastrsquo and the upstairs in the museum the story continues into World War Two in this region and even includes a look at the start of the Cold War with a virtual reality headset experience to explore inside Chapelcross, Scotlandrsquos first nuclear power station.The Devilrsquos Porridge Museum regularly tops Dumfries and Gallowayrsquos things to do on Tripadvisor and has recently been shortlisted for the prestigious lsquoMost Family Friendly Museum in the UK Award.rsquoVisit the website, Facebook, Twitteror Instagram.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Philiphaugh EstateSituated just to the North and West of the Royal Burgh of Selkirk lies Philiphaugh Estate, perhaps best known for the Civil War battle fought between the Marquis of Montrose for the Royalistsand General Leslie of the Covenanterson  September . Montrose with inferior forces was outflanked by the Covenanters and suffered total defeat thus ending the Royalist cause in Scotland.Today there is a battlefield walk from Selkirk to the Waterwheel Cafeacute , parallel to the A, Selkirk-Moffat road. Signboards describing the combatants and explaining how the battle unfolded are placed along the field where musket balls, lead shot and belt buckles have been recovered."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Philiphaugh Salmon Viewing Centre","description": "Philiphaugh Salmon Viewing Centre","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs AXuFsKY-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests AXuFsKY.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": The Waterwheel Cafeacuteprovides good value meals, tea coffee and delicious home baking. There is a car park and childrenrsquos play area. The cafeacute overlooks the ground where Montrose cut his way through the melee of soldiers to escape up the Yarrow Valley and over the Minchmoor to safety.Close by you may visit the Salmon Viewing Centre, housed in an old threshing mill. You will learn of the amazing le cycle of the Atlantic salmon. Ideal for children with a tunnel representing the riverbed, to crawl through and emerge as salmon fry! There is a computer game about the journey the salmon makes when ing to the river to spawn.An underwater camera can be selected by pressing a button on the display  and you may see fish live on the main screen. If you fail to spot anything there are recorded highlights showing salmon and sea trout and other creatures underwater. In addition, there are video clips of the major native wildle species in Scotland.There is also a working model of an Archimedes Screw turbine, which enables visitors to appreciate the workings of the Hydro station where two massive  tons Archimedes Screw Turbines are situated on the River Ettrick and generate electricity. In a year some , kwh are generated, which is enough electricity to power  houses. Salmon may be seen jumping at the cauld in high water.Pick up a pamphlet in the cafeacute or at the Salmon Viewing Centre and you will find a map showing walks: the longest leads to Harehead Hill,  feet with magnicent views to the Ettrick and Yarrow valleys and to the Cheviot and Eildon Hills. Visitors can also see the old Victorian Walled Garden where fresh fruit, vegetables, cut flowers and bedding plants may be purchased.A new attraction is a craft gin distillery. Selkirk Distillers make a delicious lsquoReiverrsquo gin and lsquoBannockrsquo gin from the internationally famous Selkirk bannock. The distillery and gardens can be accessed either by car or on foot.Set in the beautul Borders landscaped with field and woodlands carefully designed with the land form, a visit to Philiphaugh Estate will be memorable for the beauty of the countryside and the many visitor attractions grouped around the cafeacute, Hydro Station and Salmon Viewing Centre.Visitwww.salmonviewingcentreto find out more.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------CatStrandCatStrand is an award-winning arts and visitor centre in New Galloway, Scotlandrsquos smallest Royal Burgh. Ideally located within the Galloway andSouth Ayrshire Biosphere Reserve and adjacent to Galloway Forest Park and Europersquos first designated Dark Sky Park, a visit to CatStrand is a must.The cafeacute, shop and gallery are open sevendays throughout the year, selling local produce and showcasing the work of local artists and makers. A high quality programme of music,theatre, cinema, comedy, dance and visual arts is also presented in the CatStrandrsquos own auditorium and in partnership with other local venues. The popular venue has hosted many famous performers from Scotland and throughout the world such as Ricky Ross, Kiki Dee, Fred MacAulay, Judie Tzuke, Kris Drever, Ross Noble and Juan Martin.The wonderfully adaptable and fully accessible facilities are available for hire and are perfect for meetings, conferences, exhibitions, rehearsal space and celebrations.Visit Scotland awarded CatStrand  Star Arts Venue status in  and the staff are always happy to help visitors to get the very best out of this beautul corner of Scotland with local information and advice.For more information visitwww.catstrand, call  or email info@catstrand.Regular opening hours: Monday to Friday am - pm, Saturdays am-pm, Sundays am - pm.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------TraquairTraquair is Scotlandrsquos oldest, continually inhabited house set amidst the beautul rolling hills of the Scottish Borders. Its history spans over  years from when it was originally built as a hunting lodge for the kings and queens of Scotland. Amongst the animals they hunted were bears, which are now a strong emblem at Traquair.Traquair also played host to Mary Queen of Scots in  when she visited with her husband Darnley. Traquair still has the bed where she slept and the cradle where she rocked her baby, later James V of Scotland and I England."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Traquair House","description": "Traquair House","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs ebYSWHp-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests ebYSWHp.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": The Stuarts of Traquair have been in residence since  and the house remains a family home today. They were strong Catholics and Jacobites and maintained a constant loyalty to the Stuart monarchs without counting the cost. In  Bonnie Prince Charlie visited Traquair and as he left the house the Earl of Traquair closed the famous Bear Gates at the top of the avenue, promising they would remain closed until a Stuart ed to the throne. They remain closed to this day.As Catholics the family would have to practise in secret and at the top of the house a small Priestrsquos Room can be found with a secret staircase hidden behind a bookcase that could be used for a speedy escapea raid took place.In one of the wings of the house lying under the Chapel is a brew house which is now producing the world famous Traquair House Ales. Built in the rsquos to service the family and the estate it was disused in the early rsquos and lay dormant as the family junk room until it was rediscovered in the mid rsquos by the th Laird, Peter Maxwell Stuart. He started brewing again in  and beers continued to be brewed here using the original equipment, fermented in the ancient oak tuns and are exported worldwide. There is also, of course the chance to try them when you visit.As well as the house and the brewery Traquair also boasts the largest hedged maze in Scotland. Get lostyou dare!The grounds which stretch down to the River Tweed contain some stunning ancient woodlands. You can also explore four craft workshops contained in some of the old outbuildings including jewellery and leatherwork, pottery, drtwood sculpture and a range of hand made personalised fabrics.In the Old Walled Garden there is a lovely Cafeacute in the  Cottage which has won plaudits for its superb range of home baking, light lunches and snacks.The house is open to the public every day during the summer months from am ndash pm and in July and August from am ndash pm and also offers accommodation in three luxurious rooms on a bed and breakfast basis.

title: Iain Macwhirter  The SNP stands as a beacon of hope in this darkening night of populism
story: And yes, I know: the idea of this Eton-educated scion of the British upper classes being ldquoanti-establishment seems nonsensical. But populism has nothing to do with the social origins of its leaders. Nigel Farage used to be an investment banker. Donald Trump is a billionaire. It is about the people they seek to represent ndash often dismissively labelled the ldquoleft behinds, often non-graduates in low-paying jobs in non-metropolitan areas. The force that gave us Brexit.By its very nature, populism is not a coherent political philosophy. It is more visceral ndash the inarticulate fury of people who feel they the plaything of remote forces beyond their control. Its origins lay in the disruption that followed the  financial crisis, in which bankers were bailed out but not the people. They suffered insecurity, economic uncertainty and the longest pay freeze since the Napoleonic Wars.Populists linked arms with the more traditional, reactionary nationalist politicians against the globalist, liberal-democratic ldquoestablishment, that has dominated the media and politics for the last three decades. Think of Brown, Clegg and Cameron standing in line in the  election: three identikit, pro-European, neoliberal suits. Think of the leaders of the European Union. That is the establishment against which populists believe they are revolting.:Boris Johnson is asked what furniture he would need inside Number In France, the Gilet Jaunes protest continues, after nine months of street demonstrations, violent confrontations and petition-signing. It is inchoate, unpredictable and largely leaderless. But as anyone visiting France this summer will testy ndash it is everywhere. And it is overwhelmingly white. The repressive measures used against them by President Macron would be a national scandal were they used here.As Donald Trump demonstrated last week, populism has a strong racialist strand, though it is not simply a fascist movement as many on the left claim. Donald Trump is not an ideological white supremacist . He is above all an opportunist, ready to use whatever comes to hand to promote his personal popularity. With him, ratings mean more than political conviction.But that doesnt mean he can plead innocence after his genuinely shocking attacks on the democratic ldquowomen of colour last week . This began as crude electoral politics. He was trolling the Democrat Party, and the media, by singling out the radical ldquosquad of Democrat congresswomen, as theyre known. He wants the Democrats to be indelibly associated in the public mind with its multicultural Left, the better to win over white middle Americans and moderate Latinos. But he unleashed something deeply worrying.As the chants of ldquosend them home erupted at his rally Trumps trademark smirk seemed at first to nodding along. But even he now seems uneasy about the genie he has uncorked. Not since the s has racism been a factor in US presidential politics ndash at least not overtly. Barak Obama avoided playing the race card. Trump has now placed it firmly on the table, and it isnt going to go away.Donald Trumps flirtation with racism could actually lose him the next election, because many middle Americans are appalled at his behaviour. The United States prides itself, after all, on being the most multi-cultural, multi-racial society in the world ndash one which used to welcome ldquothe huddled masses of immigrants with open arms.Iain Macwhirter: Why Irsquom secretly looking forward to seeing Boris Johnson in Number TenBut liberals shouldnt get their hopes up. There is no rule that says racism cant help win elections. These are troubled times, and politicians need to exercise responsibility so as not to conjure forces they cannot control.Boris Johnson is also often called a racist, and a homophobe. This is largely because of his describing burqa-wearing Muslims as ldquobank-robbers and ldquoletter boxes. The future PM is not himself racist, as anyone who knows him can testy, but that doesnt mean he is immune to its compelling force.As London Mayor, Boris Johnson made great efforts to win the support of Muslims in that multi-racial city. He included many non-whites in his cabinet. When he takes over this week we can expect him to make great play of his progressive liberal credentials. He will remind voters that the infamousarticle argued against banning the burqa.However, there is no doubt that his signature politics of Brexit, while not racist in itself, arises at least in part from resentment at immigration. Many of Johnsons supporters are the kind of people you might find at Donald Trump rallies. His first test as Prime Minister should be to create clear multicultural water between himself and the American President ndash his equivocation last week about labelling Trumps remarks ldquoracist does not augur well.Johnson desperately needs the White House to deliver some kind of free trade deal that will show Europe that Brexit Britain means business. His first foreign visit as Prime Minister will be to the Trump Residence to plead his case for special treatment on trade. If Mr Johnson has any integrity, he will also make clear his concern at Trumps racist rhetoric ndash but I wouldnt hold my breath.Its an open secret that Johnson is looking to an early election to capitalise on Labours internal problems, which are to do with allegations of another kind of racialism: anti-Semitism. However, Westminster is now a four party political system with Nigel Farages Brexit Party and the revived Liberal Democrats challenging hard. Boris Johnson may have to seek the support of the Faragiste MPs to form a government. That could sht British politics further to the populist right.Nigel Farages party is not an overtly racist party either, though his former vehicle, Ukip, has recently been showing clear signs of becoming one. But there is no doubt that Brexit Party supporters are hostile to immigration. Racism exists as a latent force in all parties, but in nationalist ones in particular. Our own Scottish National Party used to have in its ranks ldquoanglophobes like the poet Hugh MacDiarmid, and ldquoblood and soil factions like ldquoSeed of the Gael.David Pratt: Tracing Trumps bigotryHowever, the SNP also stands as a beacon of hope in this darkening night of populism. For the party expunged all trace of anti-English racism from its ranks in the s and s. It is now arguably the most progressive, anti-racialist political party in the UK. Of course, there are still some SNP supporters around who hate English people, but they are not tolerated.There is a huge temptation for SNP politicians to subtly exploit latent anglophobia when arguing against ldquoWestminster rule. But the SNP has shown that it is possible to conduct nationalist politics with great success by avoiding these ldquotropes as theyre called. Indeed, the SNPs electoral success has largely been built on the claim that Scotland could be more progressive and more multicultural than the UK. It has raised ersity and antiracism to the level of a national political programme. In these dficult times, we should be thankful for that at least.
